Connect to Large Group  Today we read
Show the Alphabet Cards for letter
. Say the letter aloud and have children repeat.
makes the /o/ sound you hear in the word

Say the letter aloud and have children repeat.

Today we will read this book about the letter
and then we will read a book about the letter
Clap your hands when you hear a word that begins with the /o/ sound or has the /o/ sound in it.
Tap your ears when you hear a word that begins with the /p/ sound.
Model writing uppercase and lowercase letters
Provide drawing and writing supplies. Guide children in practicing forming their letters.
stop at each word that begins with the letter
. Have children say /o/ and the word that begins with
. For children who need assistance, before writing have them trace letters in salt or sand.
Encourage children to name other words that begin with
. It’s challenging to suggest categories, such as names of foods that begin with /p/. Next, ask children to name other words that have the /o/ sound as in
When reviewing the letter sounds for
by saying different words that begin with those sounds, always respond by repeating the letter sounds and names. For example, if a child answers that
begins with the /o/ sound.” Then, show the letter card and say: “/o/ is the sound of the letter

To help children with auditory discrimination challenges, exaggerate the movements of your mouth as you form each letter sound, being mindful of your tongue and lip positions. Do this while saying the sound in isolation and again as you say the sound within the picture word. Invite children to move their mouths in the same way as they make the letter sound.

paper circles, small paper circles, craft stick, glue, crayons or markers
We met a little boy with a big imagination.
We talked about Eddie’s feelings and the bear’s feelings when they lost and then found their missing teddy bears. We know how they felt and what they did.
Let’s make bear puppets. Then we can talk about how your bear can act when he feels happy, sad, surprised, angry, or scared.

Show children how to add small circles for ears to a big circle. Then have them watch as you add eyes, a nose, and a mouth to your puppet. Show them how to glue a stick to the circle to make the puppet.
Have children create their puppets. Provide help as needed. Let all the children finish before moving on.
Have children hold up their bear puppets and take turns completing sentences such as the following:
When I am a happy bear I show it by ....
When I am an angry bear, I show it by ....
When I am a disappointed bear, I show it by ....
Extend the conversation by having children talk about their own feelings and what they do when they have those feelings.

Help children participate in the conversation by asking specific concrete questions. For example, say “When you are happy, do you smile or giggle?”or “When you are angry, do you pout or stamp your feet?”
Challenge children by asking them to complete these scenarios with a word that names a feeling:

Multilingual learners sometimes need extra help because they may lack the language skills to convey their emotions. Help saying the incomplete sentences and having them act out their answers and then supplying the language.
For children who still find it difficult to draw features on a face, ahead of time prepare stickers for them to use for the eyes, nose, and mouth. Have a helper help them place the stickers.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
Connecting Cubes, two books of different sizes
We read about a little boy and a gigantic bear, and a little teddy bear and a big teddy bear. Comparing the sizes of two things can be fun!
Today, we will measure our friend’s foot and compare it to our own. There are lots of ways to measure something.
If I measure this book using Connecting Cubes, I wonder how long it is. Let’s measure!
Put the book on the table. Have children count as you connect Cubes. Announce the outcome:
This book is [16] Connecting Cubes long!
Use Connecting Cubes to measure your partner’s foot. Lay the Connecting Cubes next to your partner’s foot. When the row of Cubes is as long as their foot, count the cubes. How many Cubes long is it?
Now have your partner measure your foot in the same way. How many Connecting Cubes long is your foot?
Whose foot is longer? How do you know?
I measured my foot with Connecting Cubes too!
How can we put the Connecting Cube rows in size order? Let’s start with the shortest cube row. Who can find it?
Continue, having children place Connecting Cube rows in size order from shortest to longest. Any duplicates can remain in order.

Have each partner stand on a piece of paper. Draw lines on the paper to mark the heel and toe, and then have the child step away. Use a ruler to draw a straight line from toe to heel. Now students can more easily measure by placing Cubes directly on the straight line.
Encourage children to predict how many Cubes long they think their foot and their partner’s foot will be before they begin measuring.
ow close were they? Was it easier to predict the number of Cubes for the first or second foot? Why?

Learning about measurement introduces all children to new vocabulary. To help multilingual learners, use an online language translator or call on family support, before beginning this lesson. Learn the following measurement terms and phrases in the language of your multilingual learners:
How long? How many? How big?
When teaching, use English, followed by their home language, and then English again.

Connecting Cubes are a great way for children to strengthen their fine motor skills. If the activity is too difficult for some learners, connect cubes in a variety of lengths ahead of time. Children can line up sets of the Connecting Cubes alongside their partner’s foot. Have them try different lengths until they find the one that matches.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
Cotton ball, book, pencil, block, Connecting Cubes, straw, and other light and heavy objects, scale (balance or digital)
poster. We saw how we can measure using a ruler, a scale, cups and a thermometer.
Today, we will compare two things, guess which is heavier, and then see if we guessed correctly by using a scale to measure their weights.
Hold up a cotton ball and a book. Have children predict which is heavier. Invite children to volunteer to place each the items on the scale.
Which is heavier—the book or the cotton ball? How do you know?
If you have digital scale, compare the weight numbers and show how one is greater than the other; if you have a balance scale, show how one size is lower than the other.
Present two objects, such as a pencil and a large building block. Ask children which one they think is heavier. Then, invite two children to place the two different items on the scale.
Which is heavier? How do you know?
Repeat the activity with a variety of items until all objects have been weighed.
Comparing two items is one way to measure things.
How can we measure two things to find out which is heavier?
What happens to the side on the balance scale that has the heavier object?
If children find it difficult to make predictions about which object they think is heavier, have them close their eyes as you place an object in each hand. Then ask:
Continue, by placing these objects on the scale and having children observe.

Invite children to draw a seesaw with two animals. Have them show the animal that is heavier on the side of the seesaw that is down and the animal that is lighter on the side of the seesaw that is up.

One of the goals of this activity is to engage all learners in the process of scientific inquiry and investigation. Here are a few strategies that teachers can use to help multilingual learners accomplish this: Use actual objects, provide small-group learning with English speakers, and help children engage in hands-on exploration. Learning about measurement introduces all children to new vocabulary.

Encourage children to touch the objects being weighed and observe some of the physical characteristics that make one object heavier than another. For example, a rock is heavier than tissues rolled up into a ball of similar volume. Allow children to explore their ideas and predict the results before they weigh the objects.
